articles.headline: Why Falling Home Prices Could Be a Good Thing
articles.snippet: If we regarded our home like a TV or a car, instead of something we always expect to increase in value, there would be societal benefits.
articles.abstract: If we regarded our home like a TV or a car, instead of something we always expect to increase in value, there would be societal benefits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Suppose there were a way to pump up the economy, reduce inequality and put an end to destructive housing bubbles like the one that contributed to the Great Recession. The idea would be simple, but not easy, requiring a wholesale reframing of the United States economy and housing market.

articles.headline: The Watchdog Protecting Consumers May Be Too Effective
articles.snippet: Republicans have taken aim at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a lone safeguard for Main Street against financial predation.
articles.abstract: Republicans have taken aim at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, a lone safeguard for Main Street against financial predation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In its promise to roll back the Dodd-Frank financial reform act  of 2010, the Trump administration hasn’t provided many details. It’s a safe bet, however, that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, the federal agency charged with protecting consumers from financial miscreants, will be a target.

articles.headline: Japan Limited Immigration; Now It’s Short of Workers
articles.snippet: Japan has long tightly restricted immigration, but a shortage of low-skilled workers has politicians and companies rethinking their beliefs.
articles.abstract: Japan has long tightly restricted immigration, but a shortage of low-skilled workers has politicians and companies rethinking their beliefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: GIFU, Japan — Liu Hongmei was fed up with her job at a Shanghai clothing factory, where she worked long hours for little pay.

articles.headline: Trump Vows Quick Action to Stop Terrorism After Setback in Court
articles.snippet: While aides debated whether to appeal to the Supreme Court, the president said he may sign as early as Monday “a brand-new order” restricting travel.
articles.abstract: While aides debated whether to appeal to the Supreme Court, the president said he may sign as early as Monday “a brand-new order” restricting travel.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump vowed on Friday to order new security measures by next week intended to stop terrorists from entering the United States, even as aides debated whether to ask the Supreme Court to reinstate his original travel ban that has now been blocked by lower courts.

articles.headline: A Long Way From Mexico: Company Bets China Has an Appetite for Taco Bell
articles.snippet: Once dominant, American fast-food chains in China are now looking for answers as they face tougher competition at the high and low ends of the market.
articles.abstract: Once dominant, American fast-food chains in China are now looking for answers as they face tougher competition at the high and low ends of the market.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — Until he was appointed manager of a Taco Bell in China, Will Cao had never seen a taco before. When confronted with its hard, U-shaped shell in Los Angeles last June, he wondered: How do you eat it?

articles.headline: Former A.I.G. Executives Reach Settlement in Accounting Fraud Case
articles.snippet: Maurice Greenberg fought New York’s attorney general for over a decade, but he and another A.I.G. executive have settled the case for almost $10 million.
articles.abstract: Maurice Greenberg fought New York’s attorney general for over a decade, but he and another A.I.G. executive have settled the case for almost $10 million.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maurice R. Greenberg, the former chief executive of American International Group, reached an unexpected settlement ending a tumultuous, decade-long battle over civil accounting fraud charges first brought in 2005 by New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer.

articles.headline: Illegal Voting Gets Texas Woman 8 Years in Prison, and Certain Deportation
articles.snippet: Rosa Maria Ortega, a permanent resident, voted illegally in 2012 and 2014. Her punishment was strikingly harsh for an offense that usually merits far less jail time, if any.
articles.abstract: Rosa Maria Ortega, a permanent resident, voted illegally in 2012 and 2014. Her punishment was strikingly harsh for an offense that usually merits far less jail time, if any.
articles.lead_paragraph: Despite repeated statements by Republican political leaders that American elections are rife with illegal voting, credible reports of fraud have been hard to find and convictions rarer still.

articles.headline: Breaking Up the Family as a Way to Break Up the Mob
articles.snippet: An Italian magistrate separates children from their mob families and moves them elsewhere in Italy to interrupt a generational cycle of criminality.
articles.abstract: An Italian magistrate separates children from their mob families and moves them elsewhere in Italy to interrupt a generational cycle of criminality.
articles.lead_paragraph: REGGIO CALABRIA, Italy — Fighting the mafia at the very toe of Italy, Roberto Di Bella has seen a lot: children as young as 11 or 12 serving as lookouts during murders, attending drug deals and mob strategy sessions, or learning how to handle a Kalashnikov assault rifle.

articles.headline: Shopping Becomes a Political Act in the Trump Era
articles.snippet: Handbags, dresses and other ordinary items — and where they are bought — have become politicized, turning shopping decisions into acts of protest for the millions.
articles.abstract: Handbags, dresses and other ordinary items — and where they are bought — have become politicized, turning shopping decisions into acts of protest for the millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: A couple of weeks ago, people boycotted Nordstrom for one reason: The department store sold Ivanka Trump products.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Trump Foreign Policy Quickly Loses Its Sharp Edge
articles.snippet: He is proving to be less of a radical than either his campaign statements or his tempestuous early phone calls with foreign leaders would suggest.
articles.abstract: He is proving to be less of a radical than either his campaign statements or his tempestuous early phone calls with foreign leaders would suggest.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When President Trump took a phone call from the leader of Taiwan in December and asserted that the United States might no longer be bound by the “One China” policy, his defenders hailed it as a show of strength — the latest delicate issue on which Mr. Trump was willing to challenge decades of diplomatic orthodoxy.

articles.headline: ‘A Sense of Dread’ for Civil Servants Shaken by Trump Transition
articles.snippet: Across the nation’s bureaucracy, the new administration’s upending of protocol and policy has stirred frustration, fear and, for some, talk of resistance.
articles.abstract: Across the nation’s bureaucracy, the new administration’s upending of protocol and policy has stirred frustration, fear and, for some, talk of resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Across the vast federal bureaucracy, Donald J. Trump’s arrival in the White House has spread anxiety, frustration, fear and resistance among many of the two million nonpolitical civil servants who say they work for the public, not a particular president.
articles.byline: By Michael D. Shear and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: State G.O.P. Leaders Move Swiftly as Party Bickers in Congress
articles.snippet: Republicans in Washington appear flummoxed by one-party rule, but rising party leaders in the states are quickly passing laws to further a conservative agenda.
articles.abstract: Republicans in Washington appear flummoxed by one-party rule, but rising party leaders in the states are quickly passing laws to further a conservative agenda.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Republicans in Kentucky seized total control of the state government last year, Damon Thayer, the majority leader in the State Senate, began asking around for advice from counterparts in other capitals where the party already dominated both the legislative and executive branches.
articles.byline: By Alexander Burns and Mitch Smith

articles.headline: For Kushner, Israel Policy May Be Shaped by the Personal
articles.snippet: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, has a long connection to Israel. When he meets with the country’s prime minister on Wednesday, it will be a gathering influenced by old encounters and shared experiences.
articles.abstract: Jared Kushner, President Trump’s son-in-law, has a long connection to Israel. When he meets with the country’s prime minister on Wednesday, it will be a gathering influenced by old encounters and shared experiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Jared Kushner was 17 years old, he stood where a million Jews had been murdered and listened to Israel’s prime minister stress the country’s importance.

articles.headline: Spyware’s Odd Targets: Backers of Mexico’s Soda Tax
articles.snippet: The first hints that the phones of nutrition policy makers were infected were strange messages from unknown contacts.
articles.abstract: The first hints that the phones of nutrition policy makers were infected were strange messages from unknown contacts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Last summer, Dr. Simón Barquera’s phone started buzzing with a series of disturbing text messages from unknown numbers. One said his daughter had been in a serious accident. Another claimed to be from a friend whose father had died — with a link to funeral details.

articles.headline: Trump Sons Forge Ahead Without Father, Expanding and Navigating Conflicts
articles.snippet: Critics say conflicts of interest are far from resolved, but Don Jr. and Eric press on with deals landing Trump-branded properties around the world.
articles.abstract: Critics say conflicts of interest are far from resolved, but Don Jr. and Eric press on with deals landing Trump-branded properties around the world.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s old office on the 26th floor of Trump Tower in Manhattan sits unoccupied now, unofficial storage space for the gathering trove of memorabilia that his two oldest sons say they hope will eventually be turned over to their father’s presidential library.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Susanne Craig

articles.headline: Activism Hits Even the Less Flashy Tech Companies
articles.snippet: Prompted by President Trump’s immigration order and in some cases their employer’s own past, workers seek to set limits on cooperation with the administration.
articles.abstract: Prompted by President Trump’s immigration order and in some cases their employer’s own past, workers seek to set limits on cooperation with the administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — As soon as President Trump signed his executive order on immigration, some of the biggest tech companies went quiet. Their executives did not sign legal briefs, brandish statements or dissent on Twitter. They strove for business as usual.

articles.headline: Asian Tech Titans Take a Page From Trump’s Book
articles.snippet: Deal makers like Jack Ma have promised to make big investments and create plentiful jobs in the United States. Real, or “truthful hyperbole”?
articles.abstract: Deal makers like Jack Ma have promised to make big investments and create plentiful jobs in the United States. Real, or “truthful hyperbole”?
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In his book on deal making, President Trump offered a key piece of advice on getting what you want: Promise big.

articles.headline: Turmoil at the National Security Council, From the Top Down
articles.snippet: Staff members are struggling to make policy to fit the president’s Twitter posts, and the council’s leader, Michael T. Flynn, is facing an inquiry into his communications with Russia.
articles.abstract: Staff members are struggling to make policy to fit the president’s Twitter posts, and the council’s leader, Michael T. Flynn, is facing an inquiry into his communications with Russia.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the weekend, The Times published this investigation into the agency that Michael T. Flynn was leading before he stepped down. Read our updated article on Mr. Flynn’s resignation.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Amazon’s Living Lab: Reimagining Retail on Seattle Streets
articles.snippet: The company is putting its stamp on the city with an expanding array of unconventional experiments in bricks-and-mortar sales.
articles.abstract: The company is putting its stamp on the city with an expanding array of unconventional experiments in bricks-and-mortar sales.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — On a busy stretch of road in this city’s Ballard neighborhood, a curious new grocery store is taking shape — and so begins another effort by Amazon to use the residents of its hometown as guinea pigs.

articles.headline: When a Pillar of the Fourth Estate Rests on a Trump-Murdoch Axis
articles.snippet: The ties between Rupert Murdoch and President Trump are undeniably close, writes our media columnist. But what does that mean for the press, and the rest of us?
articles.abstract: The ties between Rupert Murdoch and President Trump are undeniably close, writes our media columnist. But what does that mean for the press, and the rest of us?
articles.lead_paragraph: The ties that bind the most powerful media mogul in the world to the leader of the free world just keep getting stronger. Or, more precisely, we keep learning just how strong they are.

articles.headline: As Japan Ages, Menus Adapt to Finding the Gourmet in Purées
articles.snippet: The country is a global leader in the kinds of societal changes needed for an aging society, including when it comes to “one of the greatest joys” — eating.
articles.abstract: The country is a global leader in the kinds of societal changes needed for an aging society, including when it comes to “one of the greatest joys” — eating.
articles.lead_paragraph: YOKOHAMA, Japan — The 94-year-old man had come for lunch at a Chinese restaurant, and he was determined to make the most of his squid and leek stir-fry.

articles.headline: Profitable Pickups May Be in Cross Hairs of Trump Border Tax
articles.snippet: Trucks from General Motors and Chrysler rely heavily on Mexican labor and parts. If a tariff wall goes up, Ford could benefit at their expense.
articles.abstract: Trucks from General Motors and Chrysler rely heavily on Mexican labor and parts. If a tariff wall goes up, Ford could benefit at their expense.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — There are many reasons for the steady success of the three major American automakers in recent years, but none are bigger than the surging sales of full-size pickup trucks.
